messageBody:
On Wed, 17 Nov 2004 11:59:39 +0000 (GMT), Yagiz Erkan
<yagiz_erkan@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
>
> We've been debating about keeping the programmer tests in the same package as
> the code (they reside in physically separated folder structures) or in a
> separate package structure. I think it is a good practice to keep the tests as
> clients to the code. This implies that the tested "units" are public. However,
> it seems to be a good package design to have a small external interface,
> without revealing the internal activity. Testing the public interface, in this
> case, makes the units too coarse grained and it isn't satisfactory. Isn't that
> a good argument to keep the programmer tests in the same package structure as
> the code?


It is for this reason that many of us do keep the tests in the same
package as the code - but in a separate source tree. That way you get
to have tests run against package interfaces, but can build the
production source without them.
